title: 113_hr944
content: The "Venezuelan Liberty Act" allows for the adjustment of status of certain Venezuelans. The "Venezuelan Liberty Act" allows for the adjustment of status to permanent residence for eligible aliens who apply before April 1, 2014, and meet certain admissibility criteria. The "Venezuelan Liberty Act" allows eligible aliens to adjust their status to permanent residence without certain provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act applying. The Secretary of Homeland Security may grant waivers for inadmissibility grounds, using specific standards. The "Venezuelan Liberty Act" allows eligible Venezuelan nationals in the United States to apply for adjustment of status without needing to file a separate motion to reopen, reconsider, or vacate any existing deportation order. If the application is granted, the deportation order will be canceled; if denied, the order remains in effect. The "Venezuelan Liberty Act" applies to Venezuelan nationals in the US who have been continuously present in the country from a specific date to the date of their adjustment application. Absences of up to 180 days are allowed without breaking the continuous presence requirement. To prove the start of continuous presence, the alien must show they applied to the Secretary of Homeland Security during the required period. The "Venezuelan Liberty Act" applies to Venezuelan nationals in the US who have been continuously present in the country from a specific date to the date of their adjustment application. Absences of up to 180 days are allowed without breaking the continuous presence requirement. To prove the start of continuous presence, the alien must show they applied to the Secretary of Homeland Security for asylum, an order to show cause, exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings, adjustment of status, employment authorization, service or business in the US, or any other benefit under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security may require aliens to demonstrate physical presence in the US during a specific period. Regulations allow aliens with a final removal order to seek a stay based on filing an application. The Attorney General cannot order the removal of an alien in removal proceedings who has applied for adjustment of status, unless the Secretary of Homeland Security has denied the application. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize employment for such aliens during the application process. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize employment for aliens with pending adjustment of status applications exceeding 180 days. Spouses and children of aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence may have their status adjusted if they are nationals of Venezuela. The son or daughter must prove continuous physical presence in the US from a specific date to the application adjudication date, or be the spouse or child of an alien eligible for adjustment to permanent residence status. The alien must apply for adjustment to permanent residence status under specific conditions, including being physically present in the US at the time of application and not being inadmissible except for certain specified grounds. The application must be filed before April 1. The alien must apply for adjustment to permanent residence status before April 1, 2014. To establish continuous physical presence, the alien must show that the period began during the required presence period and can have absences of up to 180 days. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide applicants with the same right to administrative review as other adjustment applicants. The alien must apply for adjustment to permanent residence status before April 1, 2014. The Secretary of State is not required to reduce the number of immigrant visas available when an alien is granted permanent residence. The term "required presence period" is defined as the period from February 2, 1999, to March 4, 2013. The Immigration and Nationality Act provisions apply, except where specifically provided otherwise. The Secretary of Homeland Security's powers in immigration enforcement under this Act will not be affected. Eligibility for permanent residence status under this section does not prevent seeking it under other laws.
